newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Sixty-eight countries back global telecom deal.
newsitem.headline: Sixty-eight countries back global telecom deal.

text.p: Sixty-eight countries will be bound by offers they made in World Trade Organisation talks on a global pact concluded this weekend on opening the telecommunications industry to competition.
Two more, the Bahamas and St Vincent and the Grenadines, tabled their offers too late but will join the agreement in the near future.

The European Union negotiates for all its 15 members in the WTO and is officially considered a single signatory, but in this pact their individual market opening offers vary, so they are counted individually.
The following, in alphabetical order, are the countries who were on board when the pact was agreed by acclamation at the WTO on Saturday:

Antigua and Barbuda, Australia, Bangladesh, Belize, Bolivia, Brazil, Brunei Darussalam, Bulgaria, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Czech Republic, Dominica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, European Union (Austria, Belgium, Britain, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxemburg, Netherlands, Portugal, Spain, Sweden), Ghana, Grenada, Guatemala, Hong Kong, Hungary, Iceland, India, Indonesia, Israel, Ivory Coast, Jamaica, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mauritius, Mexico, Morocco, New Zealand, Norway, Pakistan, Papua-New Guinea, Peru, Philippines, Poland, Romania, Senegal, Singapore, Slovak Republic, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Switzerland, Thailand, Trinidad and Tobago, Tunisia, Turkey, United States, Venezuela.
